user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of run_usock:
```c
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct WsData *ws = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = ws->urh;
  unsigned char buf[2048];
  unsigned char *msg;
  char *text;
  ssize_t got;
  int type;
  int i;

  make_blocking (ws->sock);
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (ws->sock, (void *) buf, sizeof (buf), 0);
    if (0 >= got)
    {
      break;
    }
    msg = ws_receive_frame (buf, &got, &type);
    if (NULL == msg)
    {
      break;
    }
    if (type == WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME)
    {
      ssize_t sent;
      int buf_size;
      buf_size = snprintf (NULL, 0, "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg);
      if (0 < buf_size)
      {
        text = malloc ((size_t) buf_size + 1);
        if (NULL != text)
        {
          if (snprintf (text, (size_t) buf_size + 1,
                        "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg) == buf_size)
            sent = ws_send_frame (ws->sock, text, (size_t) buf_size);
          else
            sent = -1;
          free (text);
        }
        else
          sent = -1;
      }
      else
        sent = -1;
      free (msg);
      if (-1 == sent)
      {
        break;
      }
    }
    else
    {
      if (type == WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME)
      {
        free (msg);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_lock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++)
  {
    if (CLIENT_SOCKS[i] == ws->sock)
    {
      CLIENT_SOCKS[i] = MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
      break;
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_unlock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  free (ws);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh, MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function run_usock:
struct WsData
{
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh;
  MHD_socket sock;
}
...
struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle
...
static pthread_mutex_t MUTEX = PTHREAD_MUTEX_INITIALIZER
...
#define MAX_CLIENTS 10
...
static MHD_socket CLIENT_SOCKS[MAX_CLIENTS]
...
#define MHD_INVALID_SOCKET (-1)
...
#define WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME 1
...
#define WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME 8
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Fragments not reported here were reviewed and are not suspected of constituting dead code under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 for the following reasons: - make_blocking(ws->sock) has a visible side effect (socket mode) and could affect behavior, so it is not dead. - The ws_receive_frame call and its NULL check determine control flow (break on NULL); those operations are executed and affect subsequent behavior. - The free(msg) inside the text-frame branch is used to release the frame buffer before checking sent; removing it would change behavior (memory management), so it is not dead. - The sent variable is assigned on all paths where it is later inspected; assignments that affect control flow (break on -1) are not dead. - The final free(ws) and MHD_upgrade_action(urh, MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE) clearly affect program state and are therefore not dead. - The use of snprintf for sizing and the subsequent call chain may be inefficient but are not provably dead without runtime/semantic information; they perform observable memory allocation/IO actions. The listed suspicious fragments were selected because they contain operations that either appear redundant, are guarded by conditions that may always evaluate the same way, or omit handling for other message types (possible code paths where operations may never be executed). These warrants further investigation to confirm whether any of those operations are in fact dead code.
